comment_3:
This song, I believe, is about someone's experience with four drugs: LSD, Speed, Marijuana, and Ecstasy.
     If we start off with the mood of the song, we notice that the song is fast, happy, and even motivational in some aspects. While this is not enough to properly create the summary that the song is based off of drugs, it contributes to the theme.
     Now, if we go to the lyrical content, we see that the link between the song and drugs is pretty strong. The stanza that begins with, "I'm a shooting star leaping through the sky/Like a tiger defying the laws of gravity..." exemplifies the side effects that are common with the drug LSD in that strange hallucinations are being reported by whoever the song is about. Secondly, the mentioning of the drug speed is taken literally here, for Mercury sings the lines, "I'm a racing car passing by like Lady Godiva/I'm gonna go go go..." He then goes into the chorus, which has lines, "Two hundred degrees/That's why they call me Mister Fahrenheit" and, "Don't stop me now I'm having such a good time/I'm having a ball..." The first part of the chorus constitutes that the song's subject is "baked" -- a term suggesting that one under the influence of drugs is experiencing the consequences. The second part of the chorus, where he speaks of having a 'good time,' also contributes to the theme of the response to drugs. After the chorus, Mercury sings, "Yeah, I'm a rocket ship on my way to Mars/On a collision course..." which is a nod to marijuana because it make people "high," like a rocket in space. As a mention to the final drug, ecstasy, the song has the lines, "I am a sex machine ready to reload/Like an atom bomb about to/Oh oh oh oh oh explode..." the link here is obvious.
Overall, this song is, quite simply, about the cheerful first-person account of doing drugs.

comment_20: Something that I think must be brought up is that some of you are looking at this song from too modern a perspective. Back when it came out in 1978, topics like drugs and sex were still quite risky in rock music. If a musician blatantly sang about such topics, he/she would've garnered immediate controversy. Which Queen never did (outside of Freddie's non-musical life). Of course, today such topics are perfectly common and accepted in rock music. But back about 30 years ago, they weren't so much. So I honestly think all these interpretations about it being about "drugs" and "gay sex" (did Freddie even realize his homosexuality at the time? - I think around the time that song was written, he was actually in a relationship with some woman, whom he broke up with shortly after) are way off.
comment_21:
About sexual freedom. Most of the lines can be seen as sexual metaphores: "I'm a rocket ship on my way to Mars
On a collision course
I am a satellite I'm out of control
I am a sex machine ready to reload
Like an atom bomb about to
Oh oh oh oh oh explode/I'm a shooting star leaping through the sky
Like a tiger defying the laws of gravity
I'm a racing car passing by"

The nonmetaphores also go with this theme: "Tonight I'm going to have myself a real good time/If you wanna have a good time just give me a call"

Also notice the talk of wanting to make a man out of one person and a woman out of the next. An obvious reference to bisexuality which further compliments the theme of sexual freedom.

comment_25:
If you've ever seen their documentary Queen: Days of Our Lives, Brian May kind of explains it. Freddie at this time was becoming extremely promiscuous and attending gay bars and participating in orgies. He wrote this song as a response to his band mates who were trying to get him to slow down.

So while not every Queen song is about homosexuality, this one clearly is.
comment_26:
Interesting. Its about sex, but its sung in such a beautiful, passionate way, the completely opposite way that a lot of the modern songs about sex are played (im referring to the modern crappy pop songs that are built on materialism).
Its also interesting because Queen's early discography was very progressive rock, and their later discography was more heavy metal (the glam metal/hard rock form of heavy metal in particular)  . But this song seems to be in between as it claims attributes of both discographies (the long guitar solo courtesy of the heavy metal genre and the piano to drum syncronization courtesy of the progressive rock genre) this song could've been the point where Queen's early progressive rock discography began to give way to their later heavy metal discography.

comment_56:
Am I the only one that finds this song tragic? Mercury's vocal seems to be on the wrong side of desperate bravado, clinging onto his wild lifestyle, while it's killing him, grinning madly as his still-beating heart is torn out and thrown in his face ... staying a rockstar, staying insane and free-spirited even though his time is almost up.
While I know this was written *before* AIDS was discovered, I still think it's about death and him pleading with the Grim Reaper to give him just one more day, so he can die happy.
comment_57:
This song is incredible; one of the most fun songs to listen to. When I first heard it, I couldn't help playing it over and over again- and it never gets old. 

I understand the "sex" interpretation, but after a few listens I'm getting more of a "drug abuse" undertone: the slow, mellow beginning which jumps into the big-time, adrenaline-pumping middle (all while Freddy sings about feeling invincible and not wanting to stop) and then starts winding down again at the end... the song's form seemed to be imitating a drug high. The reference to ecstasy might be out of context, but everything else seems to fit. He says he wants to "have myself a real good time" - not "we're going to have ourselves a real good time" - which suggests to me that whatever the song's subtext is about is a solo thing. 

Regardless, an awesome rock-out song from one of the greatest bands ever.

comment_59:
Child of Music, this song was released on Jazz in 1978. I remember reading somewhere or other that Freddie was diagnosed with AIDS in the mid to late 80s. Maybe I'm wrong, but that's what I thought. And birbeck, Freddie announced that he had AIDS the day before he died (R.I.P.), so he couldn't have denied it the *day* he died, but he did publicly deny it until the day before. That does mean that he knew for at the very least his last 2 days, but probably lots longer. But I do agree with everything else you said. Not all of Freddie's songs are about AIDS, being gay, dying, or whatever else they're stereotyped to be about.

Anyway, this is just an awesome song. I think it's about just going out and having fun, living life to the fullest, as lots of other people evidently think. I need to do that some more... ;-)

comment_66:
I think Freddie's singing in the point of view of just this very fun, very free spirit who is always the life of the party, ready to show any timid guy or gal a great night on the town, hitting the discos or bars or what have you. If you want a good time, give him a call and he'll show you, turning you from a timid joykill into someone fun like he is ("Make a super-sonic man/woman of you"). The song itself is just bouncy and fun.

I think the only sex oriented aspect of this song is the fact that he and the ones he's inviting are going out on the town -- presumably to look for a mate and have some fun with them. But I don't think the song's a graphic description of a sexual act as everyone is thinking. First off, if you want to look at it that way, he's saying that he's a quick and pathetic lay, an early bird. He'd essentially be saying "I'm so fast in the sack, I'm a racing car, traveling at the speed of light! That's why they call me Mr. Fahrenheit," which is an image I seriously don't think Mercury would like to have been associated with! So, I personally rule that theory out.

comment_119:
Ok. I see many people over offended of others stating every song Queen made is about sex and AIDS.
Others saying it is about drugs --' 
Besides the stupidity there is a lot of naivety and denial.

This song is not about drugs. The word Ecstasy is referring the taste of mind of a person. This song was written before ecstasy was mainstream and before Freddy Mercury did drugs (and he never did Ecstasy). 

Most of all this song is about being on a high, an incredible non-stoppable happiness. About just wanting to have fun. It is a drug and AIDS free song. 

And IT HAS a strong reference to sex. It's more than obvious in the lyrics and most of all in Freddy Mercury life, he loved sex with both sexes (just like it shows in the song).

You could call the song ambiguous but it's obviously about happiness with it's touch of sexual pleasure (if not most of the happiness achieved sexually).

I don't agree Queen songs are most related to sex or AIDS or drugs. Many obviously are in many ways but they don't stick just to that. 

This is one of the best Queen songs in my opinion. I just can't be sad when listening to it and feel unstoppable. I wish Freddy Mercury was still among us, he is the best musician ever (And I was just 2 years old when he died). Just hope he keeps having a ball wherever he is!

comment_121: Obviously, this song has a very sexual meaning. Sometimes it's symbolic (ex. burning through the sky). Sometimes its blatant (ex. I'm a sex machine ready to explode)
comment_122: I think its a song about people who really enjoy doing something, and are really good at it, but their peers think that it is not appropriate or right for them to do that something and try and stop them. Through the song the writer seperates himself from the others trying to stop him. The line "If you want to have a good time, Just give me a call" seems to indicate he seems to be somewhat distanced from his doubters. The protagonist also seems to have an air of confidence, perhaps overconfidence and could be pushing the boundaries to do what he enjoys doing, justifing the pleas to stop.

how can anyone get confused about this song?
its so obviously just about being really up for a proper mental night out - excited about it to the point of exploding

in the song freddys saying - im soo up for a big one tonight dont bother coming if youre gonna be borign - no-ones gonna put a downer on it im going large!!!

and no doubt itll involve 80s gay club grade ecstacy (as mentioned in the lyrics) and a bit of sex - but thats just by the by really - the song is about the excitement of a big fun night out freddys got planned

also its not a selfish attitude of
oh i wanna have a good time
oh no, he wants to share the good times - so much in fact he wants to make a
'supersonic woman/man out of you'

like he knows hes in an infectiously good mood and if you give him a call and come out you really are gonna have an amazing time

oh ok i have got to mention the sex machine line - i dont think the song is about sex, he is being metaphorical here same as when he says hes a rocket ship on a collision course

i like it cos male sexual imagery is so often portrayed at aiming towards orgasm as a final goal

comment_131:
Freddy was certainly known for his obscure song lyrics, yet somehow, no matter what, he and the band always pulled them off.

Regardless of the song's meaning, whether it was/is about sex or masturbation, it takes you on one hell of a journey.

'I'm a rocketship on my way to Mars, on a collision course. I am a satellite, I'm out of control.'

It's just a really, really fun song. 
Well and truly a great journey when you listen to it.

comment_133: Logically, it's probably about cocaine. Freddie Mercury was living a very dangerous lifestyle at the time of writing this, so it was probably addressed to everyone telling him to calm down and play it a bit safer. The song most likely describes the sensation of being on cocaine.
comment_134:
Such a shame there is not a 'complain/remove comment' feature on this forum. That said, AdamGullets comment is pure tripe. Older experienced genuine Queen fans from their first days will also have paid particular attention to Brian May and other members of the band and staff interviews. Freddy wrote this song at the height of hedonistic days, his discovery of the gay/bi clubs in NYC and in his own interviews he admits that during this time he was having the time of his life, with little regard as to potential future consequences (aids had NOT been named yet) and his intentions during this time of exploration, less stigma for gay/bi men in the places/clubs he had recently 'discovered'. He himself said he wanted to live his life then as fully, fast, dangerous, being loved by as many people as he could, sexual and otherwise. People seem to either deny/claim that most of Queens music was about sex/gay/bi/aids...and whilst some of it was, much of it was not. They ALL wrote for the band, had written FIVE songs for Highlander after being asked for just one. They also wrote the Flash Gordon soundtrack, and their epic Bohemian Rhapsody was an expiramental piece turned down by multiple promoters and labels, and when finally picked up on a punt, became one of their most acknowledged masterpieces in spite of it mostly being ambiguous in its lyrics. Brian, and his other bandages were intellectuals, had varied degrees, with Brian being an amazing astronomer (with a PHD/doctorate, and also one of our most respected wildlife, climate, ecology advocates. 
I understand this forum is primarily comments that speculate on meanings, but for the love of Freddy and other artists, do some bl**dy research  first before writing thick, inane and INSULTING comments...yes, that's to the prat, yes YOU Mr AdamGullets ...proper tw*t! Ignorance can be changed with education, but Stupid is forever. ;)

comment_143:
A good song, hilarious in Shaun of the Dead, but obviously gay

Come on, with lyrics such as "Make a supersonic man out of you"? "Oh oh oh explode?" "Rocket ship on my way to mars"? "Mr Fahrenheit?" "Like Lady Godiva"? "If you wanna have a god time just give me a call?" Combine those lyrics with things like with "sex machine" and the general tempo and way of singing, and it's absolutely one of the gayest songs I've ever heard.

I've got absolutely nothing against gay people (because I'm not religious), and most Queen songs were not about homosexuality, but this song is absolutely gay. I calls it as I see it. It is a fun song though, and it was good in SOTD.

And floating around in ecstasy"
